message_1: A spaceship emits a radio signal at a frequency of 10 MHz. The spaceship is moving away from Earth at a speed of 0.8c. What frequency will an observer on Earth measure the signal at? (Assuming the speed of light in a vacuum is 3 x 10^8 m/s)
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the relativistic Doppler effect formula for frequency:

f_observed = f_source * sqrt((1 - v) / (1 + v))

where f_observed is the frequency measured by the observer on Earth, f_source is the frequency emitted by the spaceship, v is the speed of the spaceship relative to the speed of light (c), and c is the speed of light in a vacuum.

In this case, f_source = 10 MHz = 10 x 10^6 Hz, and v = 0.8c.

f_observed = (10 x 10^6 Hz) * sqrt((1 - 0.8) / (1 + 0.8))
f_observed = (10 x 10^6 Hz) * sqrt(0.2 / 1.8)
f_observed = (10 x 10^6 Hz) * sqrt(1 / 9)
f_observed = (10 x 10^6 Hz) * (1 / 3)

f_observed â‰ˆ 3.33 x 10^6 Hz

So, the observer on Earth will measure the radio signal at a frequency of approximately 3.33 MHz.
